Explanation: Absolute contraindication - NO NEEDLING EVER. Umbilicus point. Risk of infection, bowel perforation, and severe adverse events. Moxa only may be used externally.
Absolute contraindication - NO NEEDLING. Located near femoral artery and vein. High risk of vascular damage, severe bleeding, and hematoma formation.
NO NEEDLING - nipple center point. Risk of breast tissue damage, infection, and scarring. No therapeutic value. Oblique insertion near area only if needed.
Strongly moves Qi and induces uterine contractions. Can cause miscarriage or premature labor. CONTRAINDICATED until labor induction at full term (37+ weeks). Safe postpartum.
Stimulates uterus and moves Blood strongly in lower abdomen. Risk of miscarriage and premature labor. CONTRAINDICATED before 37 weeks. Used for labor induction.
Strongly descends Qi and moves Blood. Can induce uterine contractions and premature labor. FORBIDDEN during pregnancy. Safe for labor induction.

Warning_Level: 游댮 RED - PREGNANCY FORBIDDEN + HEART DISEASE
Explanation: Strongly descends Qi and can induce labor. CONTRAINDICATED in pregnancy before 37 weeks. Also FORBIDDEN in patients with heart disease history - can trigger cardiac events.
Stimulates strong uterine activity. CONTRAINDICATED in pregnancy except for turning breech presentation with moxa at 34-36 weeks. Can induce premature labor.

Warning_Level: 游댮 RED - PREGNANCY DEEP NEEDLING FORBIDDEN
Explanation: Lower abdomen point above pubic bone. No deep or perpendicular needling in pregnancy - risk of uterine puncture, placental damage, fetal harm. Shallow oblique only if absolutely necessary.

Warning_Level: 游댮 RED - PREGNANCY DEEP NEEDLING FORBIDDEN
Explanation: Strongly tonifies original Qi and affects uterus. No deep needling in pregnancy - risk of uterine damage and labor induction. Contraindicated perpendicular insertion in advanced pregnancy.

Warning_Level: 游댮 RED - PREGNANCY DEEP NEEDLING FORBIDDEN
Explanation: Located near bladder and reproductive organs. No deep needling in pregnancy. Traditional texts warn against use in women desiring future pregnancy - modern practice more nuanced.

Warning_Level: 游댮 RED - PREGNANCY DEEP NEEDLING FORBIDDEN
Explanation: Sea of Qi point - strongly moves Qi in lower abdomen. No deep or perpendicular needling during pregnancy. Risk of uterine stimulation and premature contractions.

Warning_Level: 游댮 RED - PREGNANCY DEEP NEEDLING FORBIDDEN
Explanation: Intersection of Yin meridians in lower abdomen. No deep needling in pregnancy - affects uterus and reproductive system. Can induce contractions.
Sacral foramen points - directly affect uterus and pelvic organs. CONTRAINDICATED during pregnancy - strong labor induction effect. Used only at term for delivery.
Historically forbidden in pregnancy in some traditions due to descending Qi action. Modern research shows relative safety, but use cautiously before 37 weeks. Strongly moves Qi.
Lung alarm point on chest. Lung surface 10-20mm beneath skin. NO DEEP NEEDLING - risk of pneumothorax. Maximum depth 0.5-0.8 cun perpendicular, oblique safer. Requires expert anatomy knowledge.
Upper chest near clavicle. Lung directly beneath. NO DEEP NEEDLING - high pneumothorax risk. Oblique insertion only, maximum 0.3-0.5 cun. Avoid in patients with lung disease.
Mid-axillary line on ribcage. Lung very close to surface. NO DEEP NEEDLING - extreme pneumothorax risk. Oblique only, maximum 0.3-0.5 cun. Common site of acupuncture-induced pneumothorax.
Supraclavicular fossa. Lung apex and subclavian vessels beneath. NO DEEP/PERPENDICULAR needling - risk of pneumothorax, vessel puncture. Oblique only 0.3-0.5 cun. Extreme caution required.
Upper chest points. Lung beneath intercostal spaces. OBLIQUE INSERTION ONLY - no perpendicular needling. Maximum 0.3-0.5 cun oblique. High pneumothorax risk with deep/perpendicular needling.
Breast root point on lower ribs. Lung beneath. OBLIQUE INSERTION ONLY, maximum 0.3-0.5 cun. No deep needling - pneumothorax risk. Requires careful technique.
Sternum midline - heart and lungs beneath. NO PERPENDICULAR NEEDLING. Transverse oblique along sternum only 0.3-0.5 cun. Risk of cardiac tamponade and pneumothorax with deep needling.
Chest Kidney meridian points. Lungs and heart beneath. OBLIQUE NEEDLING ONLY. KD22 specifically avoid heart. Pneumothorax and cardiac injury risk with perpendicular/deep needling.
Lateral chest near axilla. Lung close to surface. NO DEEP NEEDLING. Oblique insertion only 0.3-0.5 cun. High risk location for pneumothorax.
Liver alarm point. Lung above, liver below on right side. NO DEEP NEEDLING - pneumothorax and liver puncture risk. Oblique 0.3-0.5 cun only. Extra caution on right side.
Gallbladder alarm point below nipple. Liver and gallbladder beneath. NO DEEP NEEDLING - organ puncture risk. Oblique only 0.3-0.5 cun. Peritonitis risk.

Carotid pulse point. EXTREME CAUTION - avoid carotid artery. Perpendicular 0.3-0.8 cun ONLY if pulse avoided. Risk of stroke, hematoma, arterial damage. Contraindicated in atherosclerosis, anticoagulation.
Axillary artery center. AVOID ARTERY - palpate and needle beside vessel. Risk of severe bleeding, hematoma, nerve damage. Contraindicated in anticoagulation therapy.
Femoral pulse point. AVOID ARTERY - palpate and needle lateral to vessel. Risk of severe bleeding, hematoma, vascular damage. Contraindicated in anticoagulation.
Dorsal foot pulse point. AVOID ARTERY - needle beside vessel only. Risk of bleeding, hematoma. Contraindicated in anticoagulation and peripheral vascular disease.
Radial pulse point. AVOID ARTERY - palpate and needle avoiding vessel. Risk of bleeding, hematoma, especially with anticoagulation. Generally safer than other arterial points.
Facial artery pulse point. AVOID ARTERY. Risk of hematoma and bleeding, especially in anticoagulated patients or bleeding disorders.
Atlanto-occipital junction. Medulla oblongata and spinal cord beneath. NO DEEP NEEDLING - risk of CNS damage, paralysis, death. Maximum 0.5 cun perpendicular. Absolute expert technique required.
Base of skull. Brainstem and cerebellum beneath. NO DEEP NEEDLING - risk of CNS injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, death. Maximum 0.5-1.0 cun perpendicular. Life-threatening if improper.
Upper cervical spine region. Spinal cord relatively close. Caution with depth - maximum 0.5-0.8 cun. Risk of spinal cord injury with deep or improper needling.
C7-T1 vertebral level. Spinal cord beneath. Oblique angle safer than perpendicular. Maximum 0.5-1.0 cun. Risk of spinal cord injury and epidural hematoma with deep needling.

Inner canthus near lacrimal system and orbit. SLOW INSERTION, NO MANIPULATION. Risk of orbital hemorrhage, eye damage, infection. Patient must keep eyes closed. Requires expert technique. Maximum 0.5-1.0 cun.
Infraorbital point directly below pupil. SLOW INSERTION, NO MANIPULATION. Risk of orbital hemorrhage, globe perforation, blindness. Maximum 0.3-0.5 cun. Contraindicated in glaucoma.
Infraorbital foramen area. Risk of nerve damage and orbital injury with deep needling. NO DEEP NEEDLING. Maximum 0.3 cun perpendicular.
Above pubic bone. No deep needling in pregnancy - risk of bladder puncture and uterine stimulation. No perpendicular needling in advanced pregnancy. Safe shallow oblique.
Abdomen midline points. No perpendicular needling in pregnancy due to enlarged uterus and organs. Oblique or transverse safer. Risk of organ puncture with deep needling.
Life gate fire point. NO MOXA in males under 20 years - can over-stimulate Yang and affect development. Needling generally safe. Also caution with excessive moxa in hypertension.
Fontanel area. NO NEEDLING in infants with open fontanel (metopism) - risk of brain injury. Safe after fontanel closure. Transverse needling safer than perpendicular.
Upper abdomen point. AVOID LIVER on right side - needle on left or very superficial on right. Risk of liver puncture with deep right-sided needling.
Temporal region. Avoid temporal artery. Superficial needling only. Risk of temporal arteritis symptoms if improper technique.
Behind ear near mastoid. NO BLOODLETTING technique. Risk of excessive bleeding and infection. Shallow insertion only.
Temporal/periorbital region. Avoid temporal artery and branches. Superficial needling only. Risk of headache and bleeding.
Medial eyebrow near supraorbital notch. Risk of bleeding and nerve irritation. Oblique along bone safer. No deep or perpendicular needling.
Lateral canthus/orbit. Superficial needling only. NO MOXA due to proximity to eye. Risk of orbital injury with deep needling.
Forehead and vertex points. NO MOXA - risk of burns and scarring on exposed areas. Needling safe with proper technique.
Upper arm near brachial artery. AVOID ARTERY and nerves. Risk of hematoma and nerve damage. Palpate pulse and avoid.
Popliteal crease center. Avoid popliteal artery/vein. NO MOXA (even pole/stick moxa). Risk of deep vein thrombosis mobilization in some patients. Caution in anticoagulation.
Sacral region. NO MOXA. Risk of burns and discomfort. Needling requires awareness of sacral anatomy to avoid foramen.
T11 level spine. NO MOXA - traditional contraindication due to spleen/digestive effects. Needling safe with proper technique and depth.
Upper arm medial. NO MOXA. Needling safe. Avoid brachial vessels nearby.
Cubital crease. NO MOXA. Avoid brachial artery and median nerve. Risk of nerve damage and hematoma.
Thumb Jing-Well point. NO MOXA. Used for bloodletting (pricking). Caution in anticoagulation and bleeding disorders.
Zygomatic region. NO MOXA. Risk of facial nerve irritation and cosmetic bruising. Superficial perpendicular or oblique.
Hairline corner. NO MOXA. Avoid superficial temporal vessels. Transverse needling safer than perpendicular.
Nose area. NO MOXA. Risk of cosmetic bruising and facial swelling. Perpendicular or oblique toward nose.
Nose and mouth area. NO MOXA. GV28 in upper gum requires careful technique. Risk of bleeding and discomfort.
Lateral knee. NO MOXA. Needling safe. Avoid excessive depth near joint space.
Dorsal foot. NO MOXA. Needling safe. Avoid extensor tendons.
Temporal head region. NO MOXA. Transverse needling safe along scalp.
Web of thumb. NO MOXA traditionally (modern practice varies). Safe needling except pregnancy. Contraindicated pregnancy before 37 weeks.

Warning_Level: 游리 YELLOW - MOXA FOR BREECH ONLY
Explanation: Toe Jing-Well point. Moxa specifically used to turn breech presentation at 34-36 weeks. Otherwise caution in early pregnancy. Can induce contractions.
Patients on warfarin, heparin, DOACs, antiplatelets: increased bleeding/hematoma risk. Avoid deep needling, arterial points, and bloodletting. Apply pressure after needle removal.
Hemophilia, thrombocytopenia, liver disease with coagulopathy: high bleeding risk. Avoid acupuncture or use minimal needling with expert supervision. No bloodletting techniques.
Avoid needling through infected, inflamed, or broken skin - risk of spreading infection and cellulitis. Avoid active psoriasis, eczema, wounds, burns, and abscesses.
Avoid needling in limbs with lymphedema - risk of infection, worsening edema, and poor healing. Particularly post-mastectomy lymphedema.
Avoid needling directly into known tumor masses - theoretical risk of tumor cell mobilization. Needling elsewhere generally safe with oncologist coordination.
NO ELECTROACUPUNCTURE near pacemaker or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator - risk of device malfunction. Manual acupuncture generally safe away from device.
Patients with chronic lung disease at higher risk of pneumothorax. Extreme caution with chest needling - consider avoiding or use very superficial oblique technique only.
Avoid deep needling in lower back/abdomen with known AAA - risk of rupture. Superficial needling only with extreme caution.
Caution with spinal points in severe osteoporosis - risk of vertebral fracture with manipulation. Gentle technique essential.
Patients with history of spontaneous pneumothorax at increased risk of recurrence. Avoid or extreme caution with chest and back needling.
Diabetic patients with neuropathy may not feel pain - risk of over-needling and poor wound healing. Gentle technique, excellent sterility essential.
Immunocompromised patients (HIV, chemotherapy, immunosuppressants) at higher infection risk. Impeccable sterile technique essential. Consider avoiding in severe immunosuppression.
Uncontrolled severe hypertension increases risk of bleeding and stroke with head/neck needling. Control blood pressure first. Specific points like LR3 may help reduce BP.
Strong stimulation in epilepsy patients may trigger seizures. Gentle technique. Avoid if seizures uncontrolled. Some points may help seizure control when stable.
Patients with severe low blood pressure risk vasovagal syncope. Have patient lie down, monitor during treatment. Use gentle stimulation. Have emergency protocols ready.
Avoid needling surgical sites and abdomen for 4-6 weeks post-surgery - risk of wound dehiscence and infection. Gentle distal points safer.
Extra caution in first 12 weeks - critical fetal development period. Avoid forbidden points absolutely. Use gentle technique for other points. Many practitioners avoid strong stimulation.
Poor circulation increases infection and poor healing risk. Gentle technique, impeccable sterility. Avoid in areas with severe ischemia or gangrene.
Severe needle phobia increases vasovagal syncope risk. Patient education, lying position, minimal needles, calm environment essential. Consider alternative therapies.
Contraindicated in patients with heart disease history - can affect cardiac function and trigger events. Also forbidden in pregnancy.
Hair makes sterile technique challenging. Risk of folliculitis and scalp infection. Careful skin preparation essential. Part hair to visualize skin.
Often used for pricking/bloodletting. Contraindicated in anticoagulation and bleeding disorders. Risk of infection with improper technique. Single-use lancets essential.
Risk of joint capsule puncture with deep needling at joint lines. Can cause joint pain, effusion, and rarely septic arthritis. Proper angle and depth essential.
Needling to periosteum (bone surface) causes sharp pain. May be therapeutic but requires patient consent and tolerance. Reduce depth if too painful.
